Carr commissioned the artist F. Hamilton Jackson to create a set of nine [[lithograph]]s to publicise his Bedford Park development, including one, picturing St Michael and All Angels church, described as iconic, claiming that the suburb was "the healthiest place in the world".<ref name="SMAAA 2018">{{cite web |title=St Michael's in Health & Architecture exhibition |url=http://www.smaaa.org.uk/wp/2018/10/11/st-michael-all-angels-in-health-architecture-exhibition/ |publisher=[[St Michael and All Angels, Bedford Park]] |access-date=11 August 2021 |date=11 October 2018 |archive-date=18 January 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210118194832/https://www.smaaa.org.uk/wp/2018/10/11/st-michael-all-angels-in-health-architecture-exhibition/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The development was promoted to people who had a moderate income but who had "aesthetic sensibilities". The promotion mentioned "A Garden and a Bath Room with Hot and Cold water to every house, whatever its size", and "A Kindergarten and good Cheap Day Schools on the Estate, and a School of Art. Also Church, Club (for Ladies & Gentlemen), Stores, 'The Tabard Inn', Tennis Courts, &c."<ref name="SMAAA 2018"/>

Removed blacklisted external link

New page

Sanjar Kargar is an Afghan politician and a former member of the House of the People (Wolesi Jirga) of Afghanistan. He was elected as a representative of Faryab Province in the 17th legislative term of the Afghan Parliament in 2019, ranking third among the elected candidates in a province with nine allocated parliamentary seats.

Following the 2019 parliamentary elections, constitutional provisions of Afghanistan stipulated that sitting members of parliament would continue to serve until new elections were held. Due to the absence of subsequent parliamentary elections, members of the 17th term, including Kargar, formally remained members of parliament until the dissolution of the legislature after the political changes in Afghanistan.

Kargar is known for his political activity representing Faryab Province and for his engagement with issues concerning ethnic and regional representation in Afghanistan.

==Plot==
==Plot==
Gopi is the head of a joint family consisting of his three sons, their wives, and children. When his family decides to punish him by not talking to him for consuming alcohol, he advertises for a caretaker. The family apologizes later and is forgiven. Gopi's granddaughter Sridevi has her engagement. Krishna, who arrives with Sridevi's fiancée's family, wins everyone's hearts with his friendliness. When it is revealed that Krishna has come in response to Gopi's advertisement for a caretaker, Gopi immediately hires him.
Gopi is the head of a joint family consisting of his three sons, their wives, and children. When his family decides to punish him by not speaking to him due to his consumption of alcohol, he advertises for a caretaker. Later, the family apologises and he forgives them. Gopi's granddaughter, Sridevi, has her engagement. Krishna arrives with Sridevi's fiancée's family and wins everyone’s hearts with his friendliness. When it is revealed that Krishna has come in response to Gopi's advertisement for a caretaker, Gopi immediately hires him.


Lakshmi is Gopi's other granddaughter, who became mentally insane after witnessing the death of her parents Devaki and Vasudeva, three years back. She lives in the outhouse. Krishna befriends Lakshmi, who later starts to recover. After Sridevi's wedding, the family decides to get Lakshmi married to Chetan, her cross-cousin, who just wants to inherit her wealth. Krishna suggests they get her married after she recovers fully, but is rebuked. The next day, it is discovered that Krishna has fled with Lakshmi. With the help of a boatwoman Chukki, they reach a music college.
Lakshmi, Gopi's other granddaughter, became mentally unstable after witnessing the death of her parents, Devaki and Vasudeva, three years ago. She lives in the outhouse. Krishna befriends Lakshmi, who later begins to recover. After Sridevi's wedding, the family decides to marry Lakshmi to Chetan, her cross-cousin, who is primarily interested in inheriting her wealth. Krishna suggests that they wait to arrange her marriage until she has fully recovered, but he is rebuked. The next day, it is discovered that Krishna has fled with Lakshmi. With the help of a boatwoman named Chukki, they reach a music college.


With the help of music, Krishna helps Lakshmi, who loves music, regain her stability. Krishna and Lakshmi return to the joint family. After beating him up initially, when they find out that Lakshmi has fully recovered, the family apologizes. Lakshmi is told about her upcoming wedding. While Lakshmi thinks Krishna is the groom, the family has chosen Chetan. Krishna leaves the house. Lakshmi is shocked and returns to the outhouse. One of Gopi's friends reveals about Krishna's past.
Through music, Krishna helps Lakshmi, who loves it, regain her stability. Eventually, they return to the joint family. After initially beating him up, the family apologises when they find out that Lakshmi has fully recovered. Lakshmi is informed about her upcoming wedding. While she believes that Krishna is the groom, the family has chosen Chetan instead. Krishna leaves the house, and Lakshmi is shocked, returning to the outhouse. One of Gopi's friends reveals details about Krishna's past.


'''Past''': Krishna's real name is Shivaram Krishna, son of a hospital chairman named Ram Kumar. One day, a rich businessman soon dies in the hospital, and the blame falls on Krishna's hospital. Krishna later learns that the businessman was actually killed by his partners. He managers to obtain evidence and decide to hand over to the [[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]]. The businessman's partners learn about this, and sends their henchman to kill him on the train. However, the henchmen instead kills Lakshmi's parents, who had exchanged their seats with Krishna. On finding out that this incident made Lakshmi go insane, a guilty Krishna seeks Gopi's friend's help to take him to her house, so that he can help to treat her illness.
'''Past''': Krishna's real name is Shivaram Krishna, son of a hospital chairman named Ram Kumar. One day, a rich businessman soon dies in the hospital, and the blame falls on Krishna's hospital. Krishna later learns that the businessman was actually killed by his partners. He managers to obtain evidence and decide to hand over to the [[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]]. The businessman's partners learn about this, and sends their henchman to kill him on the train. However, the henchmen instead kills Lakshmi's parents, who had exchanged their seats with Krishna. On finding out that this incident made Lakshmi go insane, a guilty Krishna seeks Gopi's friend's help to take him to her house, so that he can help to treat her illness.

'''Canaanite and Aramaic seal inscriptions''' are short texts engraved on personal [[Seal (emblem)|seals]] and [[Bulla (seal)|bullae]] used in the [[ancient Near East]] during the [[first millennium BCE]]. Written primarily in [[Phoenician language|Phoenician]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], the inscriptions typically record personal names, [[Patronymic surname|patronymics]], titles, or brief formulas. They are an important source for the study of wider [[Canaanite and Aramaic inscriptions]], [[palaeography]] and [[onomastics]].
'''Canaanite and Aramaic seal inscriptions''' are short texts engraved on personal [[Seal (emblem)|seals]] and [[Bulla (seal)|bullae]] used in the [[ancient Near East]] during the [[first millennium BCE]]. Written primarily in [[Phoenician language|Phoenician]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], the inscriptions typically record personal names, [[Patronymic surname|patronymics]], titles, or brief formulas. They are an important source for the study of wider [[Canaanite and Aramaic inscriptions]], [[palaeography]] and [[onomastics]].

'''Roberto Cochrane Simonsen''' (February 18, 1889 – May 25, 1948) was a Brazilian [[engineer]], [[economist]], [[Businessperson|businessman]], and [[politician]]. He was an exponent of [[developmentalism]] in Brazil.
'''Roberto Cochrane Simonsen''' (February 18, 1889 – May 25, 1948) was a Brazilian [[engineer]], [[economist]], [[Businessperson|businessman]], and [[politician]]. He was an exponent of [[developmentalism]] in Brazil.


== Biography ==
== Biography ==


Born in [[Santos FC|Santos]] into a wealthy family with ties to the [[Scottish nobility]], Simonsen completed his secondary education at the Anglo-Brazilian School in [[São Paulo]] before enrolling at age 14 in the [[Polytechnic School of the University of São Paulo|Polytechnic School]], where he earned a degree in [[civil engineering]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Brasil |first=CPDOC-Centro de Pesquisa e Documentação História Contemporânea do |title=ROBERTO COCHARANE SIMONSEN |url=https://www18.fgv.br/cpdoc/acervo/dicionarios/verbete-biografico/roberto-cocharane-simonsen |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=CPDOC - Centro de Pesquisa e Documentação de História Contemporânea do Brasil |language=pt-br}}</ref> He began working at the Southern Brazil Railway and was shortly thereafter appointed General Director of Public Works for the municipal government of Santos.
Born in [[Santos FC|Santos]] into a wealthy family with ties to the [[Scottish nobility]], Simonsen completed his secondary education at the Anglo-Brazilian School in [[São Paulo]] before enrolling at age 14 in the [[Polytechnic School of the University of São Paulo|Polytechnic School]], where he earned a degree in [[civil engineering]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Brasil |first=CPDOC-Centro de Pesquisa e Documentação História Contemporânea do |title=ROBERTO COCHARANE SIMONSEN |url=https://www18.fgv.br/cpdoc/acervo/dicionarios/verbete-biografico/roberto-cocharane-simonsen |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=CPDOC - Centro de Pesquisa e Documentação de História Contemporânea do Brasil |language=pt-br}}</ref> He began working at the Southern Brazil Railway and was shortly thereafter appointed General Director of Public Works for the municipal government of Santos.


In 1912, he founded the ''Companhia Construtora de Santos''. In 1919, he initiated his career in diplomacy. Through Simonsen's connection with Pandiá Calógeras ([[:pt:Pandiá_Calógeras|pt]]), his Company carried out the construction of several headquarters for the [[Brazilian Army]].
In 1912, he founded the ''Companhia Construtora de Santos''. In 1919, he initiated his career in diplomacy. Through Simonsen's connection with Pandiá Calógeras ([[:pt:Pandiá Calógeras|pt]]), his Company carried out the construction of several headquarters for the [[Brazilian Army]].


Simonsen participated in the [[Constitutionalist Revolution|Constitutionalist Revolution of 1932]], contributing to the industrial mobilization of the [[São Paulo (state)|state of São Paulo]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Carone |first=Edgard |date=1971 |title=Roberto C. Simonsen e sua obra |url=https://www.scielo.br/j/rae/a/49CdydJYyFx4bty8qxxdXsm/?lang=pt |journal=Revista de Administração de Empresas |language=pt |volume=11 |pages=23–28 |doi=10.1590/S0034-75901971000400002 |issn=0034-7590}}</ref> After Vargas' triumph over the constitutionalists, Simonsen took part in the creation and consolidation of the School of Sociology and Politics of São Paulo ([[:pt:Fundação_Escola_de_Sociologia_e_Política_de_São_Paulo|pt]]), where he taught [[economic history of Brazil]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Carani |first=Rodrigo |date=2024-11-01 |title=A vocação da FESPSP |url=https://fespsp.org.br/institucional/a-vocacao-da-fespsp/ |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=FESPSP |language=pt-BR}}</ref> He served as federal deputee from 1933 to 1937, and as senator from 1947 to 1948.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Senador Roberto Simonsen - Senado Federal |url=https://www25.senado.leg.br/web/senadores/senador/-/perfil/2218 |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=www25.senado.leg.br}}</ref>
Simonsen participated in the [[Constitutionalist Revolution|Constitutionalist Revolution of 1932]], contributing to the industrial mobilization of the [[São Paulo (state)|state of São Paulo]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Carone |first=Edgard |date=1971 |title=Roberto C. Simonsen e sua obra |url=https://www.scielo.br/j/rae/a/49CdydJYyFx4bty8qxxdXsm/?lang=pt |journal=Revista de Administração de Empresas |language=pt |volume=11 |pages=23–28 |doi=10.1590/S0034-75901971000400002 |issn=0034-7590}}</ref> After Vargas' triumph over the constitutionalists, Simonsen took part in the creation and consolidation of the School of Sociology and Politics of São Paulo ([[:pt:Fundação Escola de Sociologia e Política de São Paulo|pt]]), where he taught [[economic history of Brazil]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Carani |first=Rodrigo |date=2024-11-01 |title=A vocação da FESPSP |url=https://fespsp.org.br/institucional/a-vocacao-da-fespsp/ |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=FESPSP |language=pt-BR}}</ref> He served as federal deputee from 1933 to 1937, and as senator from 1947 to 1948.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Senador Roberto Simonsen - Senado Federal |url=https://www25.senado.leg.br/web/senadores/senador/-/perfil/2218 |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=www25.senado.leg.br}}</ref>


He was a member of the [[National Geographic Society]], of the [[Royal Geographical Society|Royal Geographic Society]], of the [[Brazilian Historic and Geographic Institute|Instituto Histórico e Geográfico Brasileiro]], and of the [[Brazilian Academy of Letters]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Roberto Simonsen |url=https://www.academia.org.br/academicos/roberto-simonsen/biografia |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=Academia Brasileira de Letras |language=pt-br}}</ref>
He was a member of the [[National Geographic Society]], of the [[Royal Geographical Society|Royal Geographic Society]], of the [[Brazilian Historic and Geographic Institute|Instituto Histórico e Geográfico Brasileiro]], and of the [[Brazilian Academy of Letters]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Roberto Simonsen |url=https://www.academia.org.br/academicos/roberto-simonsen/biografia |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=Academia Brasileira de Letras |language=pt-br}}</ref>


He died while giving a speech at the hall of the Brazilian Academy of Letters.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Acervo : Roberto Simonsen: prelúdio à indústria |url=https://www.memoriadaeletricidade.com.br/acervo/18955/roberto-simonsen-preludio-a-industria |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=www.memoriadaeletricidade.com.br |language=pt}}</ref>
He died while giving a speech at the hall of the Brazilian Academy of Letters.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Acervo : Roberto Simonsen: prelúdio à indústria |url=https://www.memoriadaeletricidade.com.br/acervo/18955/roberto-simonsen-preludio-a-industria |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=www.memoriadaeletricidade.com.br |language=pt}}</ref>

The '''Assassination of Binbashi Halil Musa Bey''' of 1908 also known as the '''Assassination of the Binbash of Gjirokastër''' was an incident that occurred on 25 February 1908 in the town of [[Gjirokastër]] in [[Southern Albania]] when a group of 2 Albanian rebels that were a part of an armed [[Çetes|Çetë]] led by [[Çerçiz Topulli]] fired upon the Binbash of Gjirokastra and his guards as a part of an organized operation. The incident resulted in the death of the Ottoman governor and his guards.<ref name="Gawrych">{{cite book|last=Gawrych|first=George|title=The Crescent and the Eagle: Ottoman rule, Islam and the Albanians, 1874–1913|year=2006|location=London|publisher=IB Tauris|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wPOtzk-unJgC|isbn=9781845112875}}</ref>
The '''Assassination of Binbashi Halil Musa Bey''' of 1908 also known as the '''Assassination of the Binbash of Gjirokastër''' was an incident that occurred on 25 February 1908 in the town of [[Gjirokastër]] in [[Southern Albania]] when a group of two Albanian rebels that were a part of an armed [[Çetes|Çetë]] led by [[Çerçiz Topulli]] fired upon the Binbash of Gjirokastra and his guards as a part of an organized operation. The incident resulted in the death of the Ottoman governor and his guards.<ref name="Gawrych">{{cite book|last=Gawrych|first=George|title=The Crescent and the Eagle: Ottoman rule, Islam and the Albanians, 1874–1913|year=2006|location=London|publisher=IB Tauris|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wPOtzk-unJgC|isbn=9781845112875}}</ref>

==Early life==
==Early life==
Khobragade was born May 25, 1974 in [[Tarapur, Maharashtra|Tarapur]], Maharashtra, in a Buddhist family from [[Gadchiroli district|Gadchiroli]], Maharashtra.<ref name="devyani_wapo">{{cite news |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/indias-devyani-khobragade-advocated-for-womens-rights-but-underpaid-her-nanny/2013/12/20/13e23688-69a2-11e3-8b5b-a77187b716a3_story.html |title = Who is Devyani Khobragade, the Indian diplomat at the center of the firestorm? |work = The Washington Post |last = Gowen |first= Annie |date= 20 December 2013 |access-date = 7 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.ndtv.com/article/blog/blog-my-daughter-s-return-by-uttam-khobragade-470328 |title = My daughter's return |work = NDTV |last = Khobragade | first= Uttam | date= 13 January 2014 |access-date = 13 January 2014}}</ref> Khobragade's father, [[Uttam Khobragade]], was an officer in the [[Indian Administrative Service]].<ref name="devyani_wapo"/> He was also implicated in a number of corruption scandals.<ref name="dnaindia_2501449">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-acb-books-bhujbal-son-for-land-fraud-2501449|title=ACB books Bhujbal son for land fraud {{!}} Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=2017-07-14|work=dna|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="indianexpress_4429273">{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/adarsh-scam-revoke-membership-of-22-flat-owners-cbi-tells-government-again-4429273/|title=Adarsh Scam: Revoke membership of 22 flat owners, CBI tells government again|date=2016-12-16|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="indiatimes_58173494">{{Cite news|url=https://mumbaimirror.indiatimes.com/mumbai/cover-story/sweltering-summer-just-got-worse/articleshow/58173494.cms|title=Sweltering summer just got worse - Mumbai Mirror -|work=Mumbai Mirror|access-date=2017-08-29}}</ref>
Khobragade was born May 25, 1974 in [[Tarapur, Maharashtra|Tarapur]], [[Maharashtra]], in a Buddhist family from [[Gadchiroli district|Gadchiroli]], Maharashtra.<ref name="devyani_wapo">{{cite news |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/indias-devyani-khobragade-advocated-for-womens-rights-but-underpaid-her-nanny/2013/12/20/13e23688-69a2-11e3-8b5b-a77187b716a3_story.html |title = Who is Devyani Khobragade, the Indian diplomat at the center of the firestorm? |work = The Washington Post |last = Gowen |first= Annie |date= 20 December 2013 |access-date = 7 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.ndtv.com/article/blog/blog-my-daughter-s-return-by-uttam-khobragade-470328 |title = My daughter's return |work = NDTV |last = Khobragade | first= Uttam | date= 13 January 2014 |access-date = 13 January 2014}}</ref> Khobragade's father, [[Uttam Khobragade]], was an officer in the [[Indian Administrative Service]].<ref name="devyani_wapo"/> He was also implicated in a number of corruption scandals.<ref name="dnaindia_2501449">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-acb-books-bhujbal-son-for-land-fraud-2501449|title=ACB books Bhujbal son for land fraud {{!}} Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=2017-07-14|work=dna|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="indianexpress_4429273">{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/adarsh-scam-revoke-membership-of-22-flat-owners-cbi-tells-government-again-4429273/|title=Adarsh Scam: Revoke membership of 22 flat owners, CBI tells government again|date=2016-12-16|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="indiatimes_58173494">{{Cite news|url=https://mumbaimirror.indiatimes.com/mumbai/cover-story/sweltering-summer-just-got-worse/articleshow/58173494.cms|title=Sweltering summer just got worse - Mumbai Mirror -|work=Mumbai Mirror|access-date=2017-08-29}}</ref>


She attended Mount Carmel High School in [[Mumbai]]. She obtained a degree in medicine from [[King Edward Memorial Hospital and Seth Gordhandas Sunderdas Medical College]].<ref name="devyani_toi">{{cite news | title = Who is Devyani Khobragade? | url = https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Who-is-Devyani-Khobragade/articleshow/27659238.cms| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131222051522/http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-12-19/india/45376769_1_drug-addicts-devyani-khobragade-arrest| url-status = live| archive-date = 22 December 2013|date=19 December 2013 | work = [[The Times of India]] |access-date=27 December 2013}}</ref>
She attended Mount Carmel High School in [[Mumbai]]. She obtained a degree in medicine from [[King Edward Memorial Hospital and Seth Gordhandas Sunderdas Medical College]].<ref name="devyani_toi">{{cite news | title = Who is Devyani Khobragade? | url = https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Who-is-Devyani-Khobragade/articleshow/27659238.cms| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131222051522/http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-12-19/india/45376769_1_drug-addicts-devyani-khobragade-arrest| url-status = live| archive-date = 22 December 2013|date=19 December 2013 | work = [[The Times of India]] |access-date=27 December 2013}}</ref>
Line 74: Line 74:


===Undue favours in her postings===
===Undue favours in her postings===
There is a clear finding by the Supreme Court of India that Ms. Devyani Khobragade was given a posting of her choice in the [[Indian Foreign Service]] by bending and modifying the specific rules of allocation for the specific year of 1999 where she was ranked lower than a meritorious batch mate of hers, Mr. Mahaveer C Singhvi.<ref name="mahaveer_toi">{{cite news |title=MEA 'bent' rules to favour Devyani Khobragade |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/MEA-bent-rules-to-favour-Devyani-Khobragade/articleshow/27744181.cms |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225030531/http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-12-22/india/45473493_1_ifs-allotment-language |url-status=live |archive-date=25 December 2013 |access-date=22 December 2013 |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |date=22 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="mahaveer_scg">{{cite web |title= SC ruling and why Mayawati is wrong on Devyani |url= http://www.governancenow.com/news/regular-story/sc-ruling-and-why-mayawati-wrong-devyani |access-date= 22 December 2013 |publisher = Governance Now | author = BV Rao | date= December 19, 2013}}</ref><ref name="mahaveer_hindu">{{cite news |title= IFS probationer can't be sacked without inquiry |url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/ifs-probationer-cant-be-sacked-without-inquiry/article552018.ece | author = J. Venkatesan |access-date= 22 December 2013 |newspaper= The Hindu |date= August 5, 2010 }}</ref><ref name="mahaveer_dna">{{cite news |title= Supreme Court restores job, benefits to IFS officer |url= http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-supreme-court-restores-job-benefits-to-ifs-officer-1416394 | author = Rakesh Bhatnagar | access-date= 22 December 2013 |newspaper= DNA |date= July 30, 2010 }}</ref> The finding appears in the judgment of the Supreme Court of India in a case filed by the victim batch mate against the vendetta activities of the Ministry of External Affairs effecting his service in the case of [http://indiankanoon.org/doc/68739874/ Union of India v Mahaveer C Singhvi]. The Supreme Court of India in its Judgment stated "The mode of allotment was amended for the 1999 Batch in such a calculated fashion that Ms. Khobragade, who was at Serial No.7, was given her choice of German over and above the Respondent who was graded at two stages above her."<ref name="mahaveer_toi"/>
There is a clear finding by the [[Supreme Court of India]] that Ms. Devyani Khobragade was given a posting of her choice in the [[Indian Foreign Service]] by bending and modifying the specific rules of allocation for the specific year of 1999 where she was ranked lower than a meritorious batch mate of hers, Mr. Mahaveer C Singhvi.<ref name="mahaveer_toi">{{cite news |title=MEA 'bent' rules to favour Devyani Khobragade |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/MEA-bent-rules-to-favour-Devyani-Khobragade/articleshow/27744181.cms |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225030531/http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-12-22/india/45473493_1_ifs-allotment-language |url-status=live |archive-date=25 December 2013 |access-date=22 December 2013 |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |date=22 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="mahaveer_scg">{{cite web |title= SC ruling and why Mayawati is wrong on Devyani |url= http://www.governancenow.com/news/regular-story/sc-ruling-and-why-mayawati-wrong-devyani |access-date= 22 December 2013 |publisher = Governance Now | author = BV Rao | date= December 19, 2013}}</ref><ref name="mahaveer_hindu">{{cite news |title= IFS probationer can't be sacked without inquiry |url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/ifs-probationer-cant-be-sacked-without-inquiry/article552018.ece | author = J. Venkatesan |access-date= 22 December 2013 |newspaper= The Hindu |date= August 5, 2010 }}</ref><ref name="mahaveer_dna">{{cite news |title= Supreme Court restores job, benefits to IFS officer |url= http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-supreme-court-restores-job-benefits-to-ifs-officer-1416394 | author = Rakesh Bhatnagar | access-date= 22 December 2013 |newspaper= DNA |date= July 30, 2010 }}</ref> The finding appears in the judgment of the Supreme Court of India in a case filed by the victim batch mate against the vendetta activities of the Ministry of External Affairs effecting his service in the case of [http://indiankanoon.org/doc/68739874/ Union of India v Mahaveer C Singhvi]. The Supreme Court of India in its Judgment stated "The mode of allotment was amended for the 1999 Batch in such a calculated fashion that Ms. Khobragade, who was at Serial No.7, was given her choice of German over and above the Respondent who was graded at two stages above her."<ref name="mahaveer_toi"/>


=== Children's dual citizenship ===
=== Children's dual citizenship ===
After her return to India in December was asked to deposit her children's passports with the Ministry of External Affairs. It was at this time Khobragade revealed that her children had passports from two countries, India and the United States.<ref name="dual-passports"/> The ministry instated a panel headed by the Ministry's Joint Secretary of Cypher, NGO and Vigilance (CNV), A.K. Chatterjee to determine whether she had violated Central Civil Services Conduct rules. After a nine-month enquiry, the panel ruled against her and found her guilty of "serious misconduct".<ref name="devyani_th_2014-12-21">{{cite news |url = http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/devyani-penalised-for-childrens-us-passports/article6711237.ece |title = Devyani penalised for children's US passports | author = Suhasini Haidar | work = The Hindu | date = 21 December 2014 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref>
After her return to India in December was asked to deposit her children's passports with the Ministry of External Affairs. It was at this time Khobragade revealed that her children had passports from two countries, India and the United States.<ref name="dual-passports"/> The ministry instated a panel headed by the Ministry's Joint Secretary of Cypher, NGO and Vigilance (CNV), A.K. Chatterjee to determine whether she had violated Central Civil Services Conduct rules. After a nine-month enquiry, the panel ruled against her and found her guilty of "serious misconduct".<ref name="devyani_th_2014-12-21">{{cite news |url = http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/devyani-penalised-for-childrens-us-passports/article6711237.ece |title = Devyani penalised for children's US passports | author = Suhasini Haidar | work = The Hindu | date = 21 December 2014 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref>
In another administrative action, the ministry revoked the children's Indian passports.<ref name="devyani_th_2014-12-21"/> Khobragade filed a petition in Delhi High Court against this action, arguing that though Indian law forbids dual citizenship, it is permitted for minors.<ref name="devyani_et_2014-05-12">{{cite news |url = http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-05-12/news/49795348_1_dual-citizenship-devyani-khobragade-s-indian-citizenship |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723183713/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-05-12/news/49795348_1_dual-citizenship-devyani-khobragade-s-indian-citizenship |url-status = dead |archive-date = 23 July 2015 |title = Devyani Khobragade's kids eligible for dual citizenship: Ministry of Home Affairs | author = Dipanjan Roy Chaudhury | publisher = Economic Times | work = ET Bureau | date = 12 May 2014 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref> Legal opinion holds that though minors born abroad are allowed to hold dual citizenship once they reach the age of majority (18 years), they have 6 months in which to decide which citizenship to go with.<ref name="devyani_toi_2015-07-24">{{cite news |url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/It-was-my-moral-and-legal-duty-to-challenge-wrong-done-to-my-kids/articleshow/48196468.cms |title = It was my moral and legal duty to challenge wrong done to my kids | author = Devyani Khobragade | publisher = Times of India | date = 24 July 2015 | access-date = 24 July 2015 }}</ref> If they fail to make the decision within that timeframe, they automatically lose Indian citizenship. It is unclear, however, whether it is legal for minors to hold both a foreign passport and an Indian passport.<ref name="cyrus_2004-12-17">{{cite news | title = Dual Citizenship For Children Born In The US To Indian Parents | url = http://www.ilw.com/articles/2004,1217-mehta.shtm | author = Cyrus Mehta | date=2004-12-17}}</ref> In May 2015, Justice Shakdher of the Delhi High Court put a hold on revoking the passports and asked the Ministry of External Affairs to explain to the court why it took this administrative action.<ref name="devyani_toi_2015-05-18">{{cite news |url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/HC-stays-order-to-revoke-passports-of-Devyani-Khobragades-kids/articleshow/47323323.cms |title = HC stays order to revoke passports of Devyani Khobragade's kids | publisher = Times of India | work = Times News Network | date = 18 May 2015| access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref>
In another administrative action, the ministry revoked the children's Indian passports.<ref name="devyani_th_2014-12-21"/> Khobragade filed a petition in [[Delhi High Court]] against this action, arguing that though Indian law forbids dual citizenship, it is permitted for minors.<ref name="devyani_et_2014-05-12">{{cite news |url = http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-05-12/news/49795348_1_dual-citizenship-devyani-khobragade-s-indian-citizenship |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723183713/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-05-12/news/49795348_1_dual-citizenship-devyani-khobragade-s-indian-citizenship |url-status = dead |archive-date = 23 July 2015 |title = Devyani Khobragade's kids eligible for dual citizenship: Ministry of Home Affairs | author = Dipanjan Roy Chaudhury | publisher = Economic Times | work = ET Bureau | date = 12 May 2014 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref> Legal opinion holds that though minors born abroad are allowed to hold dual citizenship once they reach the age of majority (18 years), they have 6 months in which to decide which citizenship to go with.<ref name="devyani_toi_2015-07-24">{{cite news |url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/It-was-my-moral-and-legal-duty-to-challenge-wrong-done-to-my-kids/articleshow/48196468.cms |title = It was my moral and legal duty to challenge wrong done to my kids | author = Devyani Khobragade | publisher = Times of India | date = 24 July 2015 | access-date = 24 July 2015 }}</ref> If they fail to make the decision within that timeframe, they automatically lose Indian citizenship. It is unclear, however, whether it is legal for minors to hold both a foreign passport and an Indian passport.<ref name="cyrus_2004-12-17">{{cite news | title = Dual Citizenship For Children Born In The US To Indian Parents | url = http://www.ilw.com/articles/2004,1217-mehta.shtm | author = Cyrus Mehta | date=2004-12-17}}</ref> In May 2015, Justice Shakdher of the Delhi High Court put a hold on revoking the passports and asked the Ministry of External Affairs to explain to the court why it took this administrative action.<ref name="devyani_toi_2015-05-18">{{cite news |url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/HC-stays-order-to-revoke-passports-of-Devyani-Khobragades-kids/articleshow/47323323.cms |title = HC stays order to revoke passports of Devyani Khobragade's kids | publisher = Times of India | work = Times News Network | date = 18 May 2015| access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref>


In a legal response to the Delhi High Court, the Ministry of External Affairs claimed that Khobragade obtained these passports for her children in violation of Indian law and without informing the ministry, thus raising questions about her "trustworthiness and integrity".<ref name="devyani_dna_2015-07-22">{{cite news |url = http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-mea-to-delhi-hc-devyani-khobragade-hid-the-fact-that-her-daughters-had-us-passports-2106450 |title = MEA to Delhi HC: Devyani Khobragade hid the fact that her daughters had US passports | publisher = Daily News and Analysis | work = Press Trust of India | date = 20 July 2015 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref><ref name="devyani_nie_2015-07-22">{{cite news |url = http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/In-Affidavit-to-High-Court-MEA-Raises-Questions-About-Devyani-Khobragades-Integrity/2015/07/20/article2931017.ece |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150722235232/http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/In-Affidavit-to-High-Court-MEA-Raises-Questions-About-Devyani-Khobragades-Integrity/2015/07/20/article2931017.ece |url-status = dead |archive-date = 22 July 2015 |title = In Affidavit to High Court, MEA Raises Questions About Devyani Khobragade's Integrity | author = Devirupa Mitra | publisher = The New Indian Express | work = Express News Service | date = 20 July 2015 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref> The ministry claimed that Khobragade obtained Indian diplomatic passports for her daughters by "suppressing material facts" which established that she "wilfully and blatantly violated the Indian Passport Act".<ref name="devyani_ht_2015-07-21">{{cite news | url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/devyani-broke-rules-and-hid-facts-mea-tells-high-court/article1-1371445.aspx | title = Devyani Khobragade broke rules and hid facts, MEA tells high court | publisher = Hindustan Times | date = 21 July 2015 | access-date = 22 July 2015 | archive-date = 21 July 2015 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150721235934/http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/devyani-broke-rules-and-hid-facts-mea-tells-high-court/article1-1371445.aspx | url-status = dead }}</ref> The ministry rejected Khobragade's petition for dual citizenship on the grounds that it is only applicable to those children who were born outside India. As Khobragade's children were born in India they do not qualify for dual citizenship according to interpretation of MHA.<ref name="devyani_oi_2015-07-22">{{cite news |url = http://www.outlookindia.com/news/article/mha-rejects-khobragades-petition-of-dual-citizenship-for-kids/907560 |title = MHA Rejects Khobragade's Petition of Dual Citizenship for Kids | publisher = Outlook India | work = Press Trust of India | date = 22 July 2015 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref> By acquiring US passports, the children had acquired US citizenship and would require a visa to travel to India, which the ministry would be willing to grant should the need arise.<ref name="devyani_th_2015-07-23_1">{{cite news |url = http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/no-dual-citizenship-for-devyanis-children/article7453153.ece |title = No dual citizenship for Devyani Khobragade's children | work = The Hindu | date = 23 July 2015 | access-date = 23 July 2015 }}</ref><ref name="devyani_">{{cite news |url = http://www.firstpost.com/india/pick-symbols-of-national-pride-carefully-what-misadventures-of-devyani-khobragade-taught-india-2354484.html |title = Pick symbols of national pride carefully: What (mis)adventures of Khobragade taught India | author = Sandip Roy | publisher = First Post | date = 22 July 2015 | access-date = 22 July 2015 }}</ref>

ministry, thus raising questions about her "trustworthiness and integrity".<ref name="devyani_dna_2015-07-22">{{cite news |url = http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-mea-to-delhi-hc-devyani-khobragade-hid-the-fact-that-her-daughters-had-us-passports-2106450 |title = MEA to Delhi HC: Devyani Khobragade hid the fact that her [[File:1894 Carl Zeiss subsidiary in London (6892932398).jpg|thumb|upright| [[Carl Zeiss AG|Carl Zeiss]] outlet in Mill Hill in 1894]]


The area's name was first recorded as Myllehill in 1547 and appears to mean "hill with a windmill".<ref>{{cite book |last=Mills |first=AD |year=2004 |title=A Dictionary of London Place-names |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=152 |isbn=0-19-860957-4}}</ref> However, the workings of the original Mill are in the building adjacent to [[The Mill Field]].
